page.name: Presentation: Assisting with Misconceptions [Video]
page.intro: Learn about assisting with math misconceptions.
page.content:
Example 1: Video of Ma and Pa Kettle

Watch the video below.  Use the lesson planning template to design a lesson to clear up the confusion that both Ma and Pa Kettle have about basic computation? 

Consider the following tips for lesson planning as you think about the Ma and Pa Kettle Video, and as you plan other lessons:

    • Asking questions, and listening to students’ responses and how they explain their reasoning provides extensive information on how to proceed in teaching new information. 
    • Looking across student work products (written or oral) and determining areas of common understanding or confusion will produce data for lesson planning. 
    • Providing opportunities for students to apply knowledge and concepts to other contexts and scenarios reveals whether students have a solid understanding of material and if you need to cover topics again or present them in alternative ways.

Example 2: Using classroom interaction to determine next steps in instruction

Read the excerpt below which presents a teacher, Mr. Lyman, interacting with his students.  He notices they are confused and tries to uncover where they are getting stuck by asking a series of questions.  Are there other questions you would pose to your students?

  “One topic that Mr. Lyman felt was not too difficult for his students was decimal addition and subtraction.  Yet he noticed that when he didn’t list the numbers vertically, one under the other with the decimal points lined up, many students made errors.  Because of comments by a few students, he began to suspect that their understanding of decimals was procedural and not very complete.  […] he noticed one group of four students incorrectly solved the computation 25-17.7 when they set up the exercise with the 2 and the 5 underneath the two 7s:"

17.7
-25   

So, he asked the following questions of the group:

  1. How are decimals the same or different from whole numbers?
  2. How is adding and subtracting decimals the same or different from adding and subtracting whole numbers?
  3. Take a minute to think about what you know about decimal numbers and how we add and subtract them.  Then I’ll talk with your group about this.”
